Context:
Program Name: Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management
Code: B122
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Domestic Tuition: $4,536.00 *
International Tuition: $17,455.00 **
Location: St. James Campus
Method of Study: Full-time
Starting Months: January, September
Program Description: Students will be prepared for careers in logistics, transportation, warehousing, exporting, planning and forecasting. The program includes supply chain management courses that allow graduates to demonstrate knowledge, skills and abilities related to both business in general and supply chain jobs in particular.
Program Outcomes:
1. Analysis of the impact of an organization's supply chain initiatives on its human resources management strategies, policies and practices.
2. Compliance of an organization with relevant national and internal law, regulations, safety requirements and professional standards.
* Domestic tuition is for Canadian students.
** International tuition is for students studying from outside Canada.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management Program B122 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text discusses various aspects of supply chain management and the importance of this industry in Canada. Here's a summary of the factual information:

1. There are approximately 881,326 workers in the Canadian supply chain sector labor force as of 2017.
2. Over 27,000 supply chain positions in Canada were unfilled in 2021, and another 66,000 openings are anticipated each year for the next five years.
3. George Brown College offers a Centre for Business program accredited by ACBSP, which includes diplomas, advanced diplomas, and degree programs focused on accounting & finance, HR, management, and marketing.
4. The college is one of only two colleges in Ontario to have earned ACBSP accreditation.
5. Students enrolled in the Centre for Business program are required to bring their own laptops due to a Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) initiative. Open access computers and equipment borrowing are available at the library learning commons.
6. The program "Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management" is offered with work experience. Students interested in this option should apply to B162.
7. George Brown College provides field education opportunities for students.
8. Career options within the supply chain industry are mentioned but not elaborated.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management Program B122 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The Centre For Business at George Brown College offers a Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management Diploma program. This program allows students a fast-track into the CSCMP Designation program, which is Canada's leading designation for supply chain professionals looking to advance their careers. Students can graduate with 37 required courses: 34 mandatory courses and 3 General Education Electives. Some of the mandatory courses may require students to complete prerequisites such as COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) or MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation). Students must also make up any failed or dropped courses before graduation. The college partners with SCMAO for this program. Possible careers in the supply chain management industry include positions such as procurement officer, customs analyst, forecasting and demand specialist, logistics analyst, supply chain specialist, and purchasing agent – materials management. Some examples of professionals in this field are Melinda Nycholat, Director, Contract Services, Defence Construction Canada, and Brent Ellis, Director, Commercial Warehouses, Wills Transfer Limited.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management Program B122 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information about a curriculum planner for a semester-based program offered by the college for the academic year 2023-2024. Students may need to make up courses they have failed or dropped before graduation, which can be done during the day or through Continuing Education. The equivalence of Continuing Education courses to those taught in the full-time program should be checked with college staff, and some courses may not be offered every semester.

The curriculum planner includes the following information for each semester:

Semester 1:
- Courses: BUS 1038 (Business Concepts I), COMM 2000 (Communicating Across Contexts), COMP 1010 (Business Computer Applications I), MARK 1049 (Supply Chain Management I), MARK 1020 (Principles of Marketing I), MATH 1008 (Math for Business & Management I)
- Pre-requisites: NONE

Semester 2:
- Courses: ECON 1031 (Microeconomics), BUS 1040 (Project Management), COMM 1034 (Professional Communications I), COMP 1115 (Business Computer Applications II), MATH 1095 (Math for Business & Management II), MATH 1008 (Math for Business & Management I), MGMT 4009 (Operations Management), MATH 1008
- Pre-requisites: NONE, COMP 1010, MATH 1008, MGMT 4009

Semester 3:
- Courses: ACCT 1036 (Principles of Accounting), MGMT 2049 (Supply Chain Management II), MGMT 4009 & COMP 1115, PSY 1129 (Organizational Behaviour), STAT 1012 (Business Statistics), BUS 1044 (Business Law), ECON 1032 (Macroeconomics)
- Pre-requisites: NONE, ACCT 1036

Semester 4:
- Courses: ACCT 2031 (Managerial Accounting), COMP 2157 (Comp. Appl. Involving Analytics), COMP 1115, HRM 1008 (Fundamentals of HR Management), MGMT 2051 (Transportation and Warehousing), MGMT 2049, MGMT 3015 (Quality Improvement Lean/Six Sigma), STS 1037 (Career Planning & Development)
- Pre-requisites: ACCT 1036, COMP 1115

Semester 5:
- Courses: One General Education Elective

The text also mentions that students may need to check with the business office staff for assistance with any special timetable requirements. Some courses may not be offered every semester.

Context:
Extracted Information:

The text provides a list of courses for Semesters 5 and 6 in a management or business program with general education elective options. Here are the factual information and entities extracted from the text:

Semester 5 and 6
MGMT 1035, Global Trade Assessment (Prerequisite: None)
MGMT 1020, Management Decision-Making (Prerequisites: None)
MGMT 4009 & ACCT 2031, Supply Chain Management III (Prerequisites: MGMT 3049 and Semester 5 completion)
MGMT 3049, Supply Chain Management II (Prerequisite: None)
BUS 1041, Small Business Management (Prerequisite: None)
BUS 1038, (Prerequisite: None)
MGMT 3025, Procurement (Prerequisites: None)
MGMT 2051, Select One General Education Elective (Prerequisite: None)

Semester 6

BUS 1055, (Prerequisite: None)
MGMT 3006, Strategic Analysis (Prerequisites: None)
COMM 1034, Human Skills (Prerequisite: None)
CMMK 1087, Human Skills (Prerequisite: None)
MGMT 3037, Supply Chain and Technology (Prerequisites: MGMT 2049 & MGMT 1020)
Select One General Education Elective (No prerequisite specified)

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Examine the connections between strategic objectives, stakeholder expectations, and supply chain functions, processes and roles to support decision-making, problem-solving, and coordination of tasks.
2. Determine the value added and financial implications of supply chain decisions on overall business profitability, efficiency, and stakeholder satisfaction.
3. Ensure supply chain activities and transactions are compliant with relevant legal, regulatory, and contractual obligations, industry and organization standards and policies for quality, health, safety, accountability, social, and environmental responsibility.
4. Use risk mitigation tools and strategies to inform supply chain management decisions.
5. Manage the acquisition and sale of goods, services, and materials in accordance with best practices and public and private sector stakeholder expectations across a variety of industries.
6. Plan and schedule material requirements and resource allocation and manage inventories for efficient production and fulfillment of customer orders and returns.
7. Manage the efficient handling and movement of goods, services, materials, and related information within and between supply chains.
8. Contribute to the identification and management of continuous improvements to functions and processes within and between supply chains.
9. Use available technologies to enhance work performance and support supply chain functions, processes, transactions, and communications.
10. Monitor relevant trends, emerging technologies, and local and global economic, political, and environmental issues to enhance work performance and guide management decisions.
11. Perform tasks in accordance with policies and procedures for workplace health and safety and industry standards and best practices.

   - International Tuition (first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023): $17,455.00
   - Additional costs: subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and later

2. Financial Assistance:
   - Approved for OSAP funding (meeting eligibility criteria)

3. Admission Requirements:
   - Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
   - Grade 12 English (C or U)
   - Grade 11 math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U)
   - Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or upgrade to achieve required credits
   - Meeting minimum requirements does not guarantee admission to the program; applicants may need higher grades than stated

4. Course Exemptions: visit Transfer guide for more information

5. English Language Proficiency: review the English proficiency requirements

Context:
The text provides information on how to apply and contact different departments for various inquiries at George Brown College. Here are the key factual information and entities extracted from the text:

1. International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
2. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
3. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
4. Information sessions are held on a regular basis, and interested individuals can sign up for an upcoming session.
5. For inquiries about domestic admission requirements, deadlines, or the admissions process, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section.
6. International students can contact recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through the International Contact Us page.
7. For financial aid-related inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section.
8. To make an appointment with an Entry Advisor for advice on program options, please review these frequently asked questions.
9. For general inquiries related to programs at the Centre for Business, contact business@georgebrown.ca or call (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160.
10. For inquiries related to the Business Administration – Supply Chain and Operations Management (B122) program, contact Robert Ruggieri at rruggieri@georgebrown.ca.

There is no mention of any specific programs offered by the college in the text.

Context: The text mentions that the program is offered out of the School of Management at George Brown College. The classes usually take place at the St. James Campus, specifically at 200 King St. E. and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. International representatives can be contacted for virtual meetings or inquiries through the International Contact Us page. Campus tours can be booked and there is a virtual tour available. Interested individuals can sign up to receive tailored resources for their application process and follow George Brown College on Instagram and LinkedIn. The form requires the user to provide their first name, last name, email address, whether they are domestic or international, and their country.
